message.content:
Substituting the given points into the equation yields two equations: \begin{align*}
3 &= 2^2+b(2)+c,\\
3 &= 4^2+b(4)+c.
\end{align*} Expanding these equations gives \begin{align*}
3 &= 4+2b+c,\\
3 &= 16+4b+c.
\end{align*} Subtracting the first equation from the second eliminates both $c$ and $b$: \[
0 = 12+2b\Rightarrow b=-6.\] We substitute this value into one of the equations (for example, the first) to find $c$: \[
3= 4-12 + c \Rightarrow c=\boxed{11}.\]
